Journal.Title: The journal of physical chemistry. A

Article.ArticleTitle: Exploring the Effect of Different Reactivity Promoters on the Oxidation of Ammonia in a Jet-Stirred Reactor.

AbstractText: The low reactivity of ammonia (NH<sub>3</sub>) is the main barrier to applying neat NH<sub>3</sub> as fuel in technical applications, such as internal combustion engines and gas turbines. Introducing combustion promoters as additives in NH<sub>3</sub>-based fuel can be a feasible solution. In this work, the oxidation of ammonia by adding different reactivity promoters, i.e., hydrogen (H<sub>2</sub>), methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), and methanol (CH<sub>3</sub>OH), was investigated in a jet-stirred reactor (JSR) at temperatures between 700 and 1200 K and at a pressure of 1 bar. The effect of ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) was also studied, starting from an extremely low temperature (450 K). Species mole fraction profiles as a function of the temperature were measured by molecular-beam mass spectrometry (MBMS). With the help of the promoters, NH<sub>3</sub> consumption can be triggered at lower temperatures than in the neat NH<sub>3</sub> case. CH<sub>3</sub>OH has the most prominent effect on enhancing the reactivity, followed by H<sub>2</sub> and CH<sub>4</sub>. Furthermore, two-stage NH<sub>3</sub> consumption was observed in NH<sub>3</sub>/CH<sub>3</sub>OH blends, whereas no such phenomenon was found by adding H<sub>2</sub> or CH<sub>4</sub>. The mechanism constructed in this work can reasonably reproduce the promoting effect of the additives on NH<sub>3</sub> oxidation. The cyanide chemistry is validated by the measurement of HCN and HNCO. The reaction CH<sub>2</sub>O + NH<sub>2</sub> ⇄ HCO + NH<sub>3</sub> is responsible for the underestimation of CH<sub>2</sub>O in NH<sub>3</sub>/CH<sub>4</sub> fuel blends. The discrepancies observed in the modeling of NH<sub>3</sub> fuel blends are mainly due to the deviations in the neat NH<sub>3</sub> case. The total rate coefficient and the branching ratio of NH<sub>2</sub> + HO<sub>2</sub> are still controversial. The high branching fraction of the chain-propagating channel NH<sub>2</sub> + HO<sub>2</sub> ⇄ H<sub>2</sub>NO + OH improves the model performance under low-pressure JSR conditions for neat NH<sub>3</sub> but overestimates the reactivity for NH<sub>3</sub> fuel blends. Based on this mechanism, the reaction pathway and rate of production analyses were conducted. The HONO-related reaction routine was found to be activated uniquely by adding CH<sub>3</sub>OH, which enhances the reactivity most significantly. It was observed from the experiment that adding ozone to the oxidant can effectively initiate NH<sub>3</sub> consumption at temperatures below 450 K but unexpectedly inhibit the NH<sub>3</sub> consumption at temperatures higher than 900 K. The preliminary mechanism reveals that adding the elementary reactions between NH<sub>3</sub>-related species and O<sub>3</sub> is effective for improving the model performance, but their rate coefficients have to be refined.
